summary: The Aviator introduces a girl to a world where she rediscovers her childhood and learns that it's human connections that matter most, and that it is only with heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.

reviews.content: That is a great movie. Unfortunately the 3D is not very well done but the story and the stop motion are great

i ugly cried like 3 times this is my favorite book and this movie is absolutely beautiful. it tells us yeah we can't stop from growing up but to never loose that inner child inside all of us. if you ever get to a point where you don't know what to do with your life i think this is a good film to watch

I wanted so hard to love this movie, and for the first half I did.  I cried at all the right places, and thought that the modern framework they built to have the aviator recount his story was well done... it reminds us that the call to childhood of St-Ex is universal. 

So then I discovered when the story ended that there were still some 40 minutes left to go... but why should this be?  And here is where everything went off the rails for my enjoyment: the little girl takes off into space to find that the business man has become some great existential threat consuming the galaxy.  The screenwriters apparently thought that this would be a good addition to the narrative, perhaps because they had no respect for Antoine's works.  In the world of St Ex, the beureaucrat is not someone to be feared.  Rather the "adults" of the narrative are prisoners themselves, trapped by false idols of "adulthood" that make their lives ultimately hollow and unfulfilling.  In the world of St Ex, the businessman is not to be feared, but rather to be pitied... he could have been mozart, but instead huddles over his account statements worried about numbers on a piece of paper.  

Make no mistake, Tonio did see a threat of the commercial nature of the world, but it was not a fear of the businessman, but rather a fear of the thing that made the businessman what he was in the first place.  The desire to be seen as serious, the materialism of consumers, the growing banality of choices that people are left making, and so on.  The directors lose this in their anti-capitalist, anti-corporation messaging because they embody the threat of a hollow life in an external being.  That's the failure, because the threat of shallow adulthood isn't from discreet entities: it is universal and it comes for us all.  

The screenwriters believed they could add their brand of modern view to St Ex's work, and in the attempt managed to tear down the very message and warning that the book gives to us.  Watch the movie, but the second you start to wonder why it hasn't ended, turn it off.
This movie is way too sad but it's amazing.
A fantastic movie with some of the best stop-motion I have seen.
This is #sogood. By the way do you have a baby?

Wow. Did I forget how to be a child? No. By the way, the best part of this movie is when it's focused on the history of The Little Prince. It's undeniably charming, touching, and with excellent characters. The real problem of The Little Prince 2015 version is the story outside The Little Prince's universe. I know that the falsely perfect atmosphere and the little girl and his mother without personality are purposeful things, but they're constantly removing me from that joyful atmosphere which I was always hoping to return. The aviator was a character who I learned to like throughout the movie, he started a little creepy but ended in a way as charming and touching as the story he was telling to the little girl. The third act is the best part, despite also being problematic. It starts thrilling, funny, and with excellent references to some characters from The Little Prince. But there's a new character (who was a brilliant idea) who makes that act return to the boring rhythm of the rest of the movie. At least, it ends well.
A philosophical journey told in an adventurous and heart-warming way.
I loved it. The story was great, the themes were amazing. My only problem was the last act.

It was a really fantastic and very creative animated family movie. It had really beautiful animation, really incredible voice cast, really marvelous characters, really astonishing music, really amazing visuals, really sensational drama and a really remarkable story. This is going to be one of my favorite animated movies I’ve ever watched in my whole life on Netflix. I highly recommend this movie to both children and adults.

Now to compare it to the book would be unfair. So I'm just gonna say this if you haven't read the book that's sad but then at least watch the movie. It conveys the same message. I won't say anything about the plot what I'll say though is this. The story itself doesn't matter if you've read it or watched it is filled with the best advice anyone could ever give you for every situation in life. It is just that good. I wouldn't be where I am now without The Little Prince. That says it all!

Beautiful; Beautiful; Beautiful! A multi-layered, extremely compelling, and enriching exploration of adulthood and what it is to 'grow up', and a failure of imagination in the grown-up world, that also gives such enlightened insights into the imagination, creativity, hope and compassion we all hold within us  from a young age. Appealing to both children and adults, it is a wonderous animation, with a stylisation that really shows you how much the creative team loved the book this is based on. Not going to lie, it had me puzzled a few times, but the wonderment and awe always ease you into its next 'passage'. I truly love how it encourages us to connect with older generations, and to feed that one-of-a-kind Rose slowly dying inside of all of us...

God, what a dystopian fucking nightmare. And what an overly demanding, stressed out and neurotic mother. I hate the way these people live their lives, so systematic like robots. That little world that she stumbles across when flying the airplane was so well done. I love how she comes in contact with the characters from the Little Prince story but in the "real world". Like the conceited man, played by Ricky Gervais, the king in the elevator and the business man. Crushing stars in order to make energy for your dystopian society. What a crazy concept. 

That whole scene of the freeing of the stars from the giant glass dome and the plane flying up into the cosmos with them was so beautiful. I actually cried lol. Part of life is being able to say goodbye but also knowing that the person will always be a part of your life as well even after death. 

Beautifully animated. I love the paper textured art. This movie shows us that it's things like greed, vanity, jealousy and pride that turn people into soulless and unimaginative adults. Never lose your sense of wonder and imagination, what it means to feel like a kid. So funny how it's the old man showing her how to feel like a kid again, what it feels like to live. The music was fantastic! It actually made me tear up during some moments because how beautifully it complemented the scene. 

Really heartfelt movie that hits deep in its messages about growing up and becoming an adult. Also clever and smart in its writing and storytelling. Fairly deep and sentimental for a kids movie, and I love that. Kids need to be challenged that way. I thought this was a fantastically beautiful tale and I would recommend it to anyone. Definitely something I would want to show my kids. I will be watching this one again.
I absolutely loved it, its really amazing. The paper animation style was great and im overwhelmed.

The little prince is a great movie for children and adults. The animation is beautiful and the story is a great adventure throughout the film. After watching this i could not find many cons about this movie it was just..well a great movie!
Beautiful visual and story and really tugs at the heart strings. A great watch for kids of all ages and all adults. This movie will strike a cord you didn't know you had
It made me cry at least 4 times. It was a beautiful story.
The movie is full of wisdom and reminders for personal application. This is a movie that will draw its viewer toward change, personal change.
The best movie!!! I always cry, is so cute
Pure confusion. A little bit creepy.
This film is an overwrought try-too-hard mess of a movie. Why people like it is beyond me. Panders to every sentimental aspect of childhood you can imagine. Read the book. Skip this movie.

the little prince has splended animation and comes from great source materiel, but the movie was very dark, it deals with grief and forggeting being a kid! I will give it credit because the movie is cute plus I enjoyed the stuff with the little girl and her adventure to find the little prince, but over all it was a decent movie.
It expertly translates the charm and heart of its masterful source material, with beautiful and stylish animation, endearing characters, and a moralistic and emotionally satisfying narrative.

I haven't read the book this film takes it's inspiration from, but from what I could basically gather the stop-motion sequences are fairly accurate to the original story, but the framing device with the CGI little girl and old man are entirely new.  The stop-motion sequences are all great.  First of all, they look beautiful, and have an eerie hypnotic quality to them.  Their storytelling is kind of in the form of fables, and highly symbolic, but the messages are timeless.  The framing device for the most part works well.  I take slight issue with it because it does work towards grounding a lot of the fables in a concrete world, and I don't know if that's really necessary.  I think kids are smarter than we give them credit for, and we don't need to put it in a world they relate to completely to make the story work.  That being said, it's a longer story now, and since they are doing it this way they do at least do it well.  The parallels work, and they never make it too modern.  It's very clearly in a world more resembling ours than the magical realism of The Little Prince's world, but there's no forced pop culture references or overly wacky comedy a la a bad Dr. Seuss film.  The climax is where I do start to take a bit of issue though.  For one, I thought the film went a little too long.  It's not even that long, but it doesn't need to be, and at the point when I was ready for it to start wrapping up I realized there was 40 minutes left because it had to take a really weird detour that doesn't totally work.  But even the parts that don't work too well aren't that bad, they're just not as good as the rest.  Because the rest of it is so good.  The stories of the Little Prince are all beautiful, and the framing device of the old man and girl and their strange friendship is genuinely touching.  It's a great film, not perfect, but still great.  It has a strong message of holding onto childhood that did get to me a little bit, and there's plenty of other sparks of truth sprinkled throughout that will be effective for kids and adults.

Really good watch, will watch again, and can recommend.

Whatever animation style this was, is almost perfect stylization for me: it is varied, so it's not boring, but not so exaggerated that it is off putting, even in the characters where that is partly the intent.

The voice acting is nearly perfect as well: Jeff Bridges, Mackenzie Foy, and Riley Osborn amazingly embody their characters.  I honestly can't imagine the movie with other actors in place.

My big problem with this one is that this is actually the 3rd part of a 3 part story that just happens to reference back to the first parts in a attempt to faux multi thread and drip feed information.  Don't get me wrong, it does build a certain amount of intrigue, but it's one of the problems with "The Lorax", the audience is installed, just give us the story, you don't have to break it up.

My other problem is that my biggest problem isn't enough to keep me complaining.  It's a touching movie about keeping a certain amount of freedom and passion in your life, and while it is necessary to meet requirements, they can't always be the only thing that matters.

An underrated* contemporary animation classic, The Little Prince already has the beautiful animation and really good voice acting in its favour, but it's the way it pays respect to its classic source material without talking down to its target audience that really makes it stand out amongst animated films.
*Thanks to Paramount abruptly cancelling the film and having it banished to Netflix...before Hollywood came up with the idea of releasing big-budget movies on streaming services to cut their losses

Great film, more "inspired by" than retelling the original book, which is a good thing. Somewhat scary for our four year old, and seemingly a bit confusing even for the seven year old. Still, beautiful and heart warming without being ingraciating or trite.

Good movie start again The Little Prince 
Start over over again.
a little fleshed out at points, but my word, dont watch this if you've lost a close family member.

What caught my attention was the stuffed fox that came to life for some of it. She kept it with her forever in this. It's always with her, I think. Overall, the movie was an interesting satire, a snobby girl and an oblivious-ly uptight mom. The old man was a bit of a nuisance, personality-wise and how he looked. The art was some nice work and some very pleasant. Yes, the way of life of those people was interesting but curt in presentation, left me wondering and still does. I didn't enjoy the denouement.

Rarely in 50 years have I seen such talent misapplied in such a grotesquely misconceived manner. There is barely 15 minutes of the transcendent original novel in this bloated, warped misfire; you'll know it by the gorgeous old-school paper animation. The new, surrounding narrative involving an overscheduled young girl and her friendship with the now-ancient Aviator gobbles up a huge chunk of the running time, and it's a dreary mess with beats we've seen 1,000 times. (Distant yet overprotective parent, hyper-pressure at too young an age, art and toys being thrown in the garbage, Adults Just Don't Understand Kids, the patronizing portrait of a "wacky" elderly person, etc.) Then halfway through, the movie takes a hard turn and goes from dumbed-down to the horrific, bastardized land of "Hook": let's take everything you loved about the original and turn it inside out! Let's try to "rediscover childhood" by...no, I can't.  Stick with re-reading the classic book, and try to pretend this horror never existed. When it was over, I wasn't just disappointed—I felt violated, and really, really angry. Like punch-someone-in-the-face angry. Under no circumstances show this to fans of the de Saint-Exupéry novel, nor to children.

The graphics to accentuate the other-worldliness of the Little Prince (when he's little) are quaint and tug on the heartstrings more than the more advanced animation technology can do. I also like the soundtrack.

If you like really good animation and a great story this movie has both. It is not just a retelling of, The Little Prince but also includes a new ending to the original and adds a new main character for the retelling.
awful. terrible story hard to follow dumb
One of the best stories ever, and a perfect movie adaptation
Extremely sweet and touching with superb performances
Sensitive and beautiful to watch. The film is faithful to the work of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
It tells the original story, as it is, but adds some layers to, reinterpretating it, getting the same incredible mesage.

As a person who loves watching movies like classics of Disney, Pixar, and DreamWorks Animation studios, when I heard about the release of this movie, I was very excited to watch what new film Netflix was going to be releasing on their platform. The Little Prince has become one of my favorite movies to date. And even though there are some things in the movie that dont necessarily match with the book, the film was nonetheless inspiring, moving, and magical. Through its use of beautiful imagery, nostalgic and taught lessons, the director of The Little Prince, was able to successfully portray a story and bring it to life for people of all ages to enjoy.  
This film not only reminded me of what it was like to be a child but also what I missed about being a little kid. It reminded me of the ways in which I used to play, jump, run, and dance around all day without caring what other people were doing or thinking.The movie reminded me of the carefree and happy thoughts and actions I used to carry out, because of the fact that as a kid, I had no worries in the world. Life was overall great when I was young, and this movie brought back so many of those memories I made when I was a toddler. 
	Mark Osborne did an excellent job of captivating scenes that were both beautiful and deep. The movie obviously used many pictures from the book but it did it in such a successful way that it appeared as if the book itself had come to life. The characters personality seemed to flow from the book as the colorful images captured the essence of the story and immersed the viewer in a world full of magic and adventure. For example, in the scene where The Little Prince and the little girl find the wilted rose on his home planet after releasing and freeing the stars, the darkness and dullness that surrounds them on planet B612, depicts the lonely, cold, melancholy, and dead feeling that engulfed the rose and planet when The Little Prince left. When the rose came back to life, the bright oranges, pinks, and red tones in the scene and background demonstrated the warmth and life returning to The Little Princes rose. 
	Not only did I enjoy this film because of its beautiful scenes, but also because of the important lessons viewers of all ages learned as the scenes progressed. The idea of growing up is one the strongest themes that is presented throughout the novel and the film. The little girl, who is convinced her whole life can be planned out like a map, has a maturity older than most kids her age. She feels like she has to act like a grown-up because everyone else around wants that for her, even her own mother. And this was not just for her but for every child in the movie. Being childish is frowned upon, but throughout her journey in the story, the little girl is able to find and truly discover what a childs life should be like. 
	Overall it was a great movie, and its one of the few movies I dont get tired of watching over and over again. Yes, there were many factors left out from the book, but it did not take away from the story and the beautiful images and scenes that made this movie a wonderful one to watch.
was a good and greatly illustrated movie. very sweet, and made me think a lot.
So faithful of the source material and with a beautiful blend of modern animation and stop-motion.
This film sums up life with its ugliness and its beauty
A movie that you can reprise and you will not be sorry of doing that. Made with love and a joyful story, The Little Prince can delight the fans of the book and family.

Heartwarming. A classic that I have grown to love more and more as I re-watch it. I have shown this movie to many people, no one has ever said a bad word about it, it's just so touching and full of heart. This is my favorite movie of all time. Period. The Animation is fantastic, the VAs do a great job, the writing is paced perfectly and done carefully, and it's themes of remembering and being young are well conveyed. Absolutely stunning. Five stars.
I was hoping for more, but it was okay. Maybe I need to watch it again.
Weird but interesting parable story that teaches a lot about retaining your inner child - worth a watch.

As heartwarming as it was sad, The Little Prince delivers in a film for the whole family as showing us profound lessons through great voice acting, simple and effective animation and a strong, satisfying story.
So good, an instant animation classic, absolutely must to watch

This movie is overrated. Yeah, it's based of a legendary kids book, but just that and some nice animation does not make it good. The main storyline has almost nothing to do with the source material and it forces down the message (which is a real shame because the book was very subtle). It's pretty harmless and cute so I guess showing it to your kid won't be a problem but it's not really a good movie, let alone a good adaptation
Deep and satisfying. “It is only with the heart that one can see rightly. What is essential is invisible to the eye.”
One of the most touching, meaningful films in a really long time.
this movie is terrible,  stupid, and irritating to watch whoever made this must have been on drugs

Bad attempt to create an "up to date" sequel. But it's terribly written and just boring. And too boot it's done in that pathetic cookie cutter pixar style animation that has been infesting our screens for 30 years. 

In short, this is trashy and it disgraces a classic and beautiful book.
Only film (that I can remember) that's made me cry twice. and I'm a competent 19 year old.

In a world where children are from the very beginning destined to live a life with rules and their programmed future, this tale makes us think we need to play, be creative and imaginative to become better people.

We all grew up. But what distinguishes being an adult or growing up as an adult? It's just about numbers or values. If there is no benefit, then throw it away. Apparently, this philosophy continues to swirl and point out who is actually wrong or right. Are you really happy or sad? The Little Prince explores two boundaries of the views of adults and children to a more complex essence. An experience and story that is captivating, flicking, but important to learn. And yes, when I say the movie is good, read the book too.
One of my favorite movies. It captures the pure essence of being young and experiencing youth in a whimsical way. In short, it’s a very happy movie
Very introspective story with unique animation and a great message.

Wow.  Just wow.  If you are French and like to sit around creating artsy metaphors for pontificating on life and the evils of capitalism while sipping wine and cheese, this movie is for you.  I recall seeing this book as a kid and not being impressed, and not much has changed.  You might say, yeah, but you didn't get the deeper meaning - yeah I got it.  It was pounded and beaten and flayed over and over again.  It just isn't coherent (which I GET is the point), and maybe I am just too OCD like the mom in the story.
I am not saying I didn't enjoy the movie - it was well done and there were some well done messages and laughs. Ironically, I enjoyed most of the movie that DIDN'T have the Prince in it.  It held my attention most of the way through, although I started to nod off at the end.  My kids seemed to enjoy it, so points there.

This film is a wonderful 3D animated story wrapped around the key story of The Little Prince. The narrative story highlights the performance pressures of the modern world and it's effects on young children while also outlining the importance of keeping one's inner child and imagination alive, even as an adult.

The story of the Little Prince itself is beautifully crafted in stop motion and perfectly captures the spirit of the original book by Antione de Saint-Exupéry.

I believe the 3D animated narrative story make the Prince's story easily accessible to Pixar lovers who are unfamiliar with the book and I am hopeful that it inspires them to read 1943 original.
Absolutely adorable! It made me cry!
Absolutely loved the movie. So many parables stitched into a nice story about growing up and not being eaten up by the world out there.

Strengths: What initially made this seem like an animated film to seek out was the voice cast. They all delivered. Paul Rudd (Mr. Prince), Mackenzie Foy (Little Girl), Jeff Bridges (Aviator), James Franco (Fox), Benicio del Toro (Snake), Marion Cottiliard (Rose), Rachel McAdams (Mother), and many others are all great here. The film works as a strong adaptation of the source material, staying true and still doing enough to be unique. It's a touching story that has plenty of emotion packed into it. What truly makes this stand out is the animation. There are several different types used throughout and all are beautifully done. It's truly stunning.

Weaknesses: The second half or so of the movie feels kind of disjointed. The plotlines are separated from the real world and that of the story being told, but it still could've been meshed together better. The parallels of the Little Girl's projected all work/no play life and the world the Little Prince grows up in make sense, but are super on the nose and that makes it feel a bit cheesy. Some characters come off as cliché and unlikable (Mother) or kind of creepy (Aviator) even if that wasn't the intention.

Overall: Thanks to the combination of a heartfelt theme, a wonderful voice cast, and fantastic animation, the Little Prince overcomes some issues to provide you with a highly enjoyable viewing.
Charming, it's been a while since i didn't looked away meanwhile i was looking a movie
Magical. No other word for it.

- Once upon a time, there was A Little Prince -

It's hard for me when I remember I'm a grown up now.

I vote, pay bills, and file taxes. I plan meals, grocery shop, and cook. When I move to a new place, I have to find a new doctor and dentist by myself (no matter how much I protest). I have to do these things to survive, so I learn them and accept them without too much fuss. But I have always been a little afraid of being "a grown up." Of forgetting what it feels like to be a child.

Thankfully, there are stories like The Little Prince.

"Once upon a time, there was a little Prince who lived on a planet that was scarcely bigger than himself, and who had need of a friend."

These words are familiar to many of us who grew up reading Le Petit Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, either the French original or one of the over 250 translations published around the world. Since 1943, its whimsical illustrations and deeply profound words have influenced kids and grown ups all over the world. And finally we have a modern major motion picture celebrating its legacy.

In this new version, we first meet a super-smart little girl (Mackenzie Foy, Interstellar) whose straight-laced mother (Rachel McAdams, Spotlight, Midnight in Paris) lives and breathes to create success in her daughter's life. I'm talking, class A helicopter parent-magnified by a total absence of Dad, who apparently just sends an obligatory snow globe every year on his daughter's birthday.

We're then introduced to an eccentric, elderly aviator (Jeff Bridges, The Giver, True Grit) next door who bursts into their life (quite literally) and introduces the little girl to his memories of a little Prince-a child, like herself, in need of a friend.

As the story goes on, the lines between reality and imagination blur. Friendship grows and arguments explode and the girl lets go of her mother's expectations to pursue something greater-though she isn't sure what. Buzzing in her head remains the the little yellow-haired, scarf-wearing Prince. Is he still out there, somewhere? Is he still a child and full of the wisdom that only children possess?

The film does a fine job of weaving in some of the most memorable, poignant moments from the original novella.

Like the Rose, who shows me that love can transform the most commonplace of creatures into something truly unique.

Like the Prince, who reminds me that love lives forever in my heart and memory, no matter what changes, ages, or dies.

Like the Aviator, who shows me that growing up is not the problem: forgetting is.

The Little Prince is a beautiful blend of a classic story and a new, compelling one. The animation is absolutely arresting, full of light, shadows, and the aura of wonder. It's the sort of movie where stars hang from threads, and you can almost hear them laughing.

I think what makes it most compelling, as its own story and as an adaptation, is the honesty with which it tackles both childhood and adulthood. Being an adult is not the perfect state, but neither is being a child. (We can't help which we are, after all.) But we begin to drift apart, we begin to lose each other, when we forget to be awestruck. When we put tasks and lists and self-interest above sacrifice, friendship, and vulnerability.

"It is only with heart that one can see rightly. What is essential is invisible to the eye."

----------

This review was first published on Narrative Muse, http://www.narrativemuse.co/movies/the-little-prince, and was written Debbie Holloway. Narrative Muse curates the best books and movies by and about women and non-binary folk on our website http://narrativemuse.co and our social media channels.

One of the most philosophical, thought-provoking, emotional movies of the century. The Little Prince is both a children's adventure tale and a tear-jerker for adults that pulls on the emotional strings, helping us come to terms with life, age, death, and beliefs. It's a real doozy.
Wonderful music, great adaptation of a great book. Top 10 family movie of all time!

This movie is adorable in every way. the story did get a little confusing when there was more than one of them. some things that were in the movie were most definitly not in the book. for example, the girl, but sometimes you have to do that in ,movies. other than that it was a cute, and interesting movie

I attempted to watch this film today in French for the first 30 mins, then switched to English and rewatched. This is a children's film for grown-ups. It's a wonderful adaptation by director Mark Osbourne to the French novel 'Le Petit Prince' by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry.
If you're an adult with years of working experience, then you can appreciate the messages conveyed in this film. The 3 different film effects differentiate the stories within the story and are all expressive and magnificent in its use of imagery. Some of the most memorable lessons are: remember to find joy in the simple things in life like we did as young children, common objects and people can become unique if you make it so, and not letting your own fears get in the way of your children's experiences. If you have made many sacrifices for wealth, have raised children, or have lost loved ones, this film can be very moving.
it was just outstanding, the graphics were amazing, the lights and colours were just incredible they fitted the movie perfectly :)

The Little Prince is a deep and meaningful film with a twist of light-hearted childlike playfulness and imagination. The film is well thoughtout and reminds it's audience that it's okay to grow up, but it's never okay to forget the child side of yourself. The script is powerful, the animation is absolutely stunning and I am in awe. This may not be the movie for those who are impatient or aren't fond with long movies, but it is 100% worth it.

There are only a few ... delightful moments in an otherwise muddled movie that feels like three films ineptly grafted together.

- Los Angeles Times
That was about a million times better than I was expecting.

It was interesting that the source material was just a story within an original plot, but it worked out well! The contrast of CGI and Stop Motion animation between the two story settings was a fantastic idea! The end was kind of strange, and it felt like a bit was missing from the book. But overall, it is a beautiful and heartfelt little movie.

The Little Prince is a decent enough animation. It’s based off a book by the same name. Maybe it makes more sense as a book in French. I can’t say it’s a movie I would rematch or recommend to a child. I don’t think they would understand what’s going on. Like which part is the “story” and which part was “reality”? There was a point where it blended together and I thought that was odd. Anyway, I suppose you might enjoy this if you area fan of the book.

I watched this movie with my family and fiancé and it quickly became my favorite. It's an indescribably beautiful and sentimental movie with a wonderful story and a wonderful message. This movie is certainly very special to me now and the messages all really resonated with me, I was brought to tears several times. I highly recommend seeing this movie, it's truly moving.

Beautiful. Started it for my son.  At the time, he was 2 and got bored watching full length feature films.  When he stated that he was bored, about an hour in, I said "Shhh...Mommy is watching this."  It is a wonderful film and like the book, a children's story for adults.  Have watched it 3 times.  Animation is gorgeous, the soundtrack perfect.  It transported me to another time and place with whimsy and lessons of life and love.
This movie has a strong message and strong story plus plenty of heart-warming moments to satisfy viewers.
I almost cried. this is great for everyone, it has a adventure and interesting topics
I’m convinced this is the best movie ever made. The way it makes you think about life is just beautiful.
The Little Prince is highly entertaining and the animation is absolutely beautiful. Every family that watches this movie will remember it for life!

With perfect voice performances from its all-star cast and a story faithful to the original source's plot and themes while also adding a new contemporary touch, "The Little Prince" benefits from its outstanding blend of CGI and stop-motion sequences and its unmatchable charm to appeal to both kids and adults.

Amazingly, this movie was better than the book.  And the book is a timeless classic.  Go see this if you have a kid.  Or if you're are a kid.  Or if you know kids or have seen kids.  Go.  I can't tell you you will cry; but I'm not going to tell you that you won't.
Shares the importance of imagination. such a beautiful movie to look at and admire.
An amazing, heart warming film that is worth seeing.
I signed up for RT just to review this movie. Such a whimsical treasure with beautiful animation and music. It's very dream like.
